page.title: French Revolutionary Wars

infobox.caption: the [[battle of valmy]] (20 september 1792)
infobox.date: {{start and end dates|1792|4|20|1802|3|25|df=yes}}<br>(9 years, 11 months, and 5 days)
infobox.result:
[[war of the first coalition|first coalition]] (french victory):
* [[peace of basel]]
* [[treaty of campo formio]]
[[war of the second coalition|second coalition]] (french victory):
* [[treaty of lunéville]]
* [[treaty of amiens]]
infobox.territory:
* fall of the [[kingdom of france (1791–92)|kingdom of france]] and establishment of the [[first french republic|french republic]]
* france annexes [[piedmont]] and all the lands west of the [[rhine]]
* establishment of the pro-french [[batavian republic|batavian]], [[helvetian republic|helvetian]], [[italian republic (napoleonic)|italian]], and [[ligurian republic|ligurian]] republics
* establishment of the [[kingdom of etruria]] in italy
* austria acquires [[republic of venice|venetia]] and [[dalmatia]]
* spain cedes [[trinidad]] to britain
* spain retrocedes [[louisiana (new france)|louisiana]] to france
* britain returns [[menorca]] to spain
* netherlands cedes [[ceylon]] to britain
* other territorial changes

page.title: Timeline of the French Revolution

infobox.Image_Caption: the execution of [[louis xvi]] on the ''place de la révolution'' (now [[place de la concorde]]) (january 21, 1793)
infobox.Result:
* [[Proclamation of the abolition of the monarchy|Abolition]] of the [[List of French monarchs|French monarchy]]
* Establishment of a secular and democratic republic that became increasingly authoritarian and militaristic
* Radical social change based on [[liberalism]] and other [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]] principles
* Rise of [[Napoleon Bonaparte]]
* [[French Revolutionary Wars|Armed conflicts]] with other European countries

page.title: Battle of Marengo

infobox.partof: the [[war of the second coalition]], [[war of the french revolution]]
infobox.image: [[image:lejeune - bataille de marengo.jpg|300px|alt=scene of the battle in which napoleon, followed by some generals, advances on horseback from the left towards the centre of the image. behind him a regiment confronts in line the head of the austrian pursuit column, while desaix is being mortally wounded at the head of his men. further to the right, gen. zach is captured by some cavalrymen and gen. saint-julien tries to escape the same fate. in the background gen. kellermann conducts his famous cavalry charge in the flank of the austrians. behind all the action lies the village of spinetta, in front of the apennines.]]
infobox.caption: ''the battle of marengo'', by [[louis-françois lejeune]].
infobox.result: decisive french victory<ref name="brauerwright1990">{{cite book|author1=brauer|author2=william e. wright|title=austria in the age of the french revolution: 1789–1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rfrofbqeg1yc&pg=pa34|accessdate=21 april 2013|date=1 december 1990|publisher=berghahn books|isbn=978-1-57181-374-9|page=34}}</ref><ref name="afflerbachstrachan2012">{{cite book|author1=holger afflerbach|author2=hew strachan|title=how fighting ends: a history of surrender|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gh6viodyxnmc&pg=pa215|accessdate=17 april 2013|date=26 july 2012|publisher=oxford university press|isbn=978-0-19-969362-7|page=215}}</ref>
infobox.commander2: [[michael von melas]]<br>[[peter karl ott von batorkez|peter ott]]
infobox.casualties1: 1,100 killed<br>3,600 wounded<br>900 missing or captured<ref name="benoit122">benoît, p. 122</ref><br>'''total: 5,600'''<ref>chandler, david g.. ''the campaigns of napoleon'', new york, 1966, {{isbn|0-02-523660-1}}, p. 296, gives: 25% total casualties.</ref>
infobox.casualties2: 6,000 dead or wounded<br>8,000 captured<br>40 guns captured<br>15 colours captured<ref name="Benoit122"/><br>'''Total: 14,000'''<ref>Chandler, David G.. ''The Campaigns of Napoleon'', New York, 1966, {{ISBN|0-02-523660-1}}, p. 296, gives: 15 colours, 40 guns, 8,000 captured and 6,000 killed. Asprey, Robert. ''The Rise of Napoleon Bonaparte'', Basic Books, 2001, {{ISBN|0-465-04881-1}}, p. 387, gives: 6,000 killed or wounded and another 6,000 captured; 15 flags, 40 cannon.</ref>

page.title: Battle of Cape Finisterre (1805)

infobox.caption: ''admiral sir robert calder's action off cape finisterre, 23 july 1805'', by [[william anderson (british/scottish artist)|william anderson]]. the captured spanish prizes ''firme'' and ''san raphael'', are under tow on the right and the damaged hms ''windsor castle'', on the left.
infobox.result: indecisive<ref>barnes, p.36 "admiral sir robert calder's squadron, stationed off ferrol, intercepted him (villeneuve) and fought a confused and inconclusive engagement.  although calder managed to capture two spanish ships, he was reprimanded, for the action had interfered with barham's plans by failing to divide the enemy fleet and thus had left the situation unaltered.</ref><ref>moors, p. 1263 "the french had twenty-seven vessels, calder but fifteen, and after an indecisive battle, in which two spanish ships were taken, he was afraid to renew the engagement, and villeneuve was thus enabled to reach ferrol in safety.</ref><ref>alfred thayer mahan, p 303. "two spanish ships-of-the-line were captured, but the battle was otherwise indecisive. calder hesitated to attack again, and on the 26th lost sight of the enemy, who, on the 28th, put into vigo bay"</ref><ref>alexander myrick broadley,p.224</ref><ref name="brytant p. 154">brytant p. 154</ref><br> british strategic victory<ref>palmer, p. 198 ''the british although outnumbered by a third, had won the day''</ref><ref>tucker p. 1039, ''calder had a won victory with an inferior force''</ref><ref>stewart p. 54 ''cape finisterre was a serious defeat for napoleon''</ref><ref>marriott p. 280 ''sir robert calder's victory over villeneuve at cape finisterre on 22 july 1805'' [https://books.google.com/books?id=9esoaaaaqaaj&pg=pa280&dq=calder+victory+1805&hl=en&sa=x&ei=izakunaniyg_0qwajidgag&ved=0cdaq6aewaa#v=onepage&q=calder%20victory%201805&f=false] p.280</ref>
infobox.commander2:
{{flagicon|france}} [[pierre charles silvestre de villeneuve|pierre de villeneuve]],<br>
{{flagicon|spain}} [[federico gravina]]
infobox.casualties1: 198 dead or wounded<ref name="tucker, pg 1039">tucker, pg 1039</ref>
infobox.casualties2: 647 dead or wounded,<ref name="tucker, pg 1039"/><br>2 ships captured,<br>1,200 prisoners<ref>palmer, p.198</ref>

page.title: Switzerland in the Napoleonic era

infobox.status_text: [[client state]] of the [[first french empire|french empire]]
infobox.symbol_type:
coat of arms<ref name=coa>the confederacy had no official coat of arms during this period, as the cantons were fully sovereign and each used their own coats of arms. but some cantons would mint coins where on the reverse side the confederation was represented with a coat of arms inscribed "xix cant" or "xix cantone", e.g. ''20 [[batzen]]'' coin minted by aargau, 1809 ([http://www.moneymuseum.com/de/muenzen/katalog?&id=688 moneymuseum.org]), the ''1 franken'' coin minted by berne in 1811 ([http://www.moneymuseum.com/de/muenzen/katalog?&id=115 moneymuseum.com]), or the ''4 franken'' coin minted by solothurn in 1813 ([http://www.moneymuseum.com/de/muenzen/katalog?&id=240 moneymuseum.com]).
use of the [[swiss cross]] to represent the confederacy only recurred in 1815, under the [[restored swiss confederacy]].</ref>

page.title: Battle of Winterthur

infobox.partof: the [[french revolutionary wars]] – [[war of the second coalition]]
infobox.image: topographic map of battle of winterthur 1799.svg
infobox.caption: the [[swiss plateau]] stretches southwest to northeast, from switzerland's border with france, to the shores of lake constance. on the southern flank of the plateau, the alps block access to the italian states; on the north flank of the plateau, a series of moderate hills rim the rhine. the battleground, south of lake constance, is depicted with a star. the battle helped to secure austria's control of the northeastern swiss plateau.
infobox.commander1: [[friedrich freiherr von hotze]]<br />[[friedrich joseph, count of nauendorf]]
infobox.commander2: [[michel ney]], commanding elements of the [[army of the danube]]
